contents.context:
A gas leak at an LG Polymers plant in southern India on Thursday has killed at least 9 people with more than 300 admitted to hospital.
Among those hospitalized, more than 70 are unconscious, according to police in Andhra Pradesh state.
Police say chemical gas had leaked from two of the plant's 5,ton tanks but, because of the COVID-19 lockdown, there were significantly fewer workers on site than normal.
However, more than a thousand people in the surrounding area have been forced to evacuate their homes as they have been experiencing difficulty breathing and with sore eyes.
The Indian government has dispatched rescue teams along with the police to investigate.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Gas leak at LG Polymers plant in India kills 9, hundreds hospitalized
Updated: 2020-05-07 17:10:55 KST

contents.context:
Starting in mid-April, states in the U.S. have moved to ease lockdowns and reopen the economy as President Trump announced guidelines based on three phases.

"A prolonged lockdown, combined with a forced economic depression, would inflict an immense and wide-ranging toll on public health."

The guidelines include keeping good personal hygiene and ensuring social distancing.
And as states succeed in going through the three phases without a surge of COVID-19 patients, they can allow more travel and public interaction.
According to CNN, 43 out of 50 states will have reopened in part by the end of this week.
In California, some stores like flower shops and bookstores will open and Mississippi will allow gatherings of over 20 people.
However, there are concerns on whether this is the right time for the U.S. to ease lockdowns.
President Trump himself, in an interview with ABC News on Tuesday, acknowledged that the death toll could rise as the U.S. reopens its economy.
Experts in the U.S. point out there haven't been enough safety measures and a number of states have not satisfied the conditions required to lift their lockdowns for example, seeing new cases drop for 14 consecutive days.
A public poll by the Washington Post suggests 82-percent of American citizens oppose the reopening of movie theaters and 78-percent are against sports facilities reopening.
According to the U.S. Department of Health, the number of confirmed cases in the U.S. has surpassed 126-thousand and the death toll is almost 71-thousand, the highest in the world.
Oh Jung-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
43 out of 50 U.S. states to reopen economy in part by end of this week
Updated: 2020-05-07 17:03:05 KST

contents.context:
A political party in France has praised South Korea's response to the COVID-19 outbreak.
The Center-right opposition party The Republicans urged France to use South Korea as a role model, and praised the Korean public's community spirit.
The party's report also highlighted Seoul's use of technology, such as smartphone apps, to rapidly respond to cluster infections.
France's death toll from COVID-19 has now topped 25-thousand.
The French government says it's planning to ease travel restrictions next week.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
French opposition party The Republicans publishes report praising S. Korea's response to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-07 17:01:34 KST

contents.context:
The number of global COVID-19 cases has surpassed 3.7 million, and the global death toll has topped 260-thousand.
Russia has been reporting over 10-thousand new cases a day for the past four consecutive days, with its accumulated number of cases at over 165-thousand as of Wednesday.
Russia's culture minister has also been diagnosed with COVID-19 , the fourth top Russian official to have contracted the virus.
The UK has now leapfrogged Italy to have the highest number of COVID-19 deaths in Europe, with its death toll surpassing the 30-thousand mark.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel said Wednesday that the country had passed the first phase of the pandemic, and shops will be allowed to open.
She explained that the public will be required to maintain social distancing until June 5th, but added the country's football league Bundesliga will restart in mid-May with no spectators, becoming Europe's first major league to resume.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Number of global COVID-19 cases surpasses 3.7 million, global death toll standing over 260,000
Updated: 2020-05-07 10:07:10 KST

contents.context:
Speaking at a press conference in Washington on Wednesday, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo reaffirmed the U.S. has significant evidence the COVID-19 virus originated from a certain laboratory in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

"We don't have certainty. And there is significant evidence that this came from the laboratory. Those statements can both be true. "

Two laboratories were researching coronavirus in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, before the pandemic started.
The theory that COVID-19 might've come from there was given further traction last week when President Trump suggested he was confident the Wuhan Institute of Virology was the origin.
The WHO says it's waiting on an invitation from China to take part in its investigation into the animal origins of the virus that was first reported in Wuhan in December 2019.
However, Beijing's UN ambassador in Geneva says Beijing's top priority is first beating the pandemic, then countering what he called an "absurd and ridiculous" accusation from the U.S.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry also accused Washington of engaging what it called political manipulation.

"We are opposed to individual politicians in the United States conducting investigations based on the presumption of guilt on China for domestic political reasons. We are opposed to using the epidemic to engage in political manipulation."

Beijing says President Trump and Pompeo's allegations about the source of the virus are simply them trying to "shift responsibility" over their failed response to the outbreak in the U.S.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Significant evidence China hid truth about origins of COVID-19: Pompeo
Updated: 2020-05-07 10:03:24 KST

contents.context:
The European Union's economy is on track to contract by 7.4 percent this year following the global COVID-19 pandemic, shrinking at a higher rate than during the Great Recession in the 1930s.
The European Commission said Wednesday that investment is expected to collapse while unemployment rates and deficits are to skyrocket.
It forecasts that Italy, one of the hardest hit countries of the virus, will see its economy shrink by 9.5 percent, while significant damage is also expected for Spain and Greece, countries that depend heavily on tourism.
Unemployment in the 19 eurozone countries will increase to 9.6 percent this year, and slowly decline to 7.9 percent in 2021.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
EU to witness deepest recession in history following COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-07 07:19:39 KST

contents.context:
The COVID-19 pandemic triggered the worst wave of unemployment in the United States in almost 20 years in April.
Over 20 million private sector jobs were lost last month alone in the U.S.
This is according to American management services company Automatic Data Processing on Wednesday.
Service sectors, including business and financial, leisure and hospitality, shed more than 16 million jobs.
April's job figures set to be released by the U.S. Labor Department on Friday are expected to be worse, with the jobless rate forecast to be around 15 percent.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. private payrolls drop by historic 20.2 mil. in April: ADP
Updated: 2020-05-07 05:57:42 KST

contents.context:
COVID-19 has now infected over 3.6 million people globally and killed over 255-thousand.
In addition, it is taking a massive toll on leading world economies.
The U.S. trade deficit for March widened almost 12-percent as the virus grounded international flights, froze the global tourism industry and caused disruptions to commerce.
The UK's service sector activity dropped to lowest level on record last month.
In Spain, unemployment is at a near four year high with 3.8 million people out of work.
Brazil is feeling the pinch as well.
Its industrial production plunged more than expected in March to levels not seen since 2003.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Economies around world suffer amid COVID-19 pandemic
Updated: 2020-05-06 10:07:25 KST

contents.context:
U.S. President Donald Trump has threatened China that Washington could walk away from the phase one trade deal with Beijing, which briefly put the trade war between the world's two largest economies at rest.
According to the White House Tuesday, President Trump said the trade deal could be terminated if Beijing does not make good on its commitment to buy 250 billion U.S. dollars-worth of U.S. goods.
During a Fox News virtual town hall meeting on Sunday, President Trump added he's also mulling additional tariffs on Beijing, which he called (quote) the "ultimate punishment."
Senior Trump administration officials have already floated the idea of restarting tariffs on China to hold the country accountable for its role as the original epicenter of the COVID-19 outbreak and for Beijing's lack of communication with the world at critical stages.
U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is continuing to slam Beijing, saying China has a history of infecting the world.
President Trump's trade adviser Peter Navarro also said this week that the Chinese Communist Party lied about the spread of the virus, which has led to the deaths of many across the world.
An expert on China issues at the American Enterprise Institute told U.S.-based Foreign Policy that President Trump will continue to ratchet up his hostile rhetoric against Beijing as he prepares for the presidential election in November.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Trump threatens to terminate phase one trade deal with China if Beijing fails to purchase US$ 250 bil. of American goods
Updated: 2020-05-06 10:06:27 KST

contents.context:
U.S. President Donald Trump says Washington will release its report which details of the origins of COVID-19 in time, without elaborating on when.
Speaking at the White House Tuesday, Trump said the report will definitely be disclosed over a period of time, adding many people ask him about the virus' origin.
He also called for the Chinese government to be transparent.
The remark adds to his administration's aggressive rhetoric against China as it looks to pin the blame on Beijing for the COVID-19 pandemic.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
U.S. to release report on details of COVID-19 origin over time: Trump
Updated: 2020-05-06 10:06:24 KST

contents.context:
Pirates off the coast of Gabon reportedly attacked two fishing vessels on Sunday kidnapping one South Korean, three Indonesians and two Senegalese crewmen.
AFP reported the news, saying that the Gulf of Guinea in west Africa has become the new epicenter for pirate attacks and that this is the second attack off the coast of Gabon this year.
In April, a pirate attack on a container ship left eight sailors missing.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Pirates off coast of Gabon abduct six crewmen: AFP
Updated: 2020-05-06 10:04:29 KST

contents.context:
The European Commission is looking to intensify its scrutiny of money-laundering risks in more than 20 states.
A document expected to be published on Thursday …has added Panama and 11 other countries to its blacklist that already includes North Korea, Afghanistan and Iraq.
However, Saudi Arabia, Libya and four U.S. territories that had been put on an earlier draft were removed from the list.
The revised list of 22 states is set to take effect from October.
Another document suggests giving the European Union more power to tackle the issue, …including creating a new supervisory body to monitor banks by 2023.
All countries on the list except North Korea have committed to changing their system to tackle money laundering and terrorism financing.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
EU to intensify scrutiny of money-laundering risks in 22 states
Updated: 2020-05-06 08:56:48 KST
